sections.title: Beyond Client-Server Architecture
sections.content: The web's foundational architecture is changing. What began with simple file-sharing has matured into sophisticated distributed systems capable of running entire applications without centralized servers. From CRDTs to content addressing, we're witnessing the emergence of truly distributed computing.

sections.title: Reclaiming Digital Sovereignty
sections.content: As platform consolidation accelerates, peer-to-peer technologies offer an alternative path. These systems eliminate single points of control, enable offline-first applications, and return data ownership to users. The question isn't whether decentralization will happen, but how quickly we can build better tools.

sections.title: The Interoperability Challenge
sections.content: Today's decentralized ecosystem resembles the early web - brilliant innovations trapped in incompatible silos. Developers face difficult choices between protocols, limiting adoption and fragmenting user experiences. We need bridges, not walls.

sections.title: Standards as Infrastructure
sections.content: The most successful technologies become invisible infrastructure. Just as HTTP enabled the web's explosive growth, shared protocols for peer-to-peer systems can unlock exponential possibilities. Standards don't limit innovation - they enable it at scale.

sections.title: The Technical Foundations
sections.content: Core building blocks are already emerging: IPLD for content addressing, DIDs for identity, CRDTs for synchronization, DHTs for discovery, and libp2p for transport. These modular components can compose into systems more powerful than any single protocol.

sections.title: Building the Next Web
sections.content: The transition to decentralized systems requires collaboration across projects, protocols, and communities. OpenHaven documents the landscape and advocates for standards that enable interoperability. The future web will be local-first, user-owned, and globally connected.
